Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Story:
I was folding laundry in the living room, sorting socks and shirts so my wife wouldn’t have to scramble for clean clothes before her early meeting. The kids’ uniforms needed to be ready for tomorrow, and I’d promised to help more around the house. My phone buzzed with a reminder: I had to be in court in an hour. As I slipped on my suit, I felt the weight of both roles pressing in.

In the courtroom, I was deep into jury instructions when my clerk rushed over, eyes wide, and handed me a note. The Supreme Court had just overturned the precedent my instructions relied on. I could feel the jurors’ eyes on me, waiting. I knew I had to stop, review the new ruling, and rewrite everything on the spot. My mind raced—if I delayed, the trial would be thrown into chaos, but if I rushed, I might misapply the law. At the same time, I remembered the half-finished laundry at home, the promise I’d made to my wife, and the guilt of letting her down again. I stood there, torn, the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which demand to answer first.
